header.rec_loc: In the ticket office at Creech-St- Michael.
header.topics: Work, boating, building, model engineering, family matters.
header.activity: Taking a break from the working party.

speaker.dialect_rep: I may have a slight Somerset accent
speaker.occupation: retired artist and antique dealer/gallery owner

body.u: right it's really good of you to talk to me today so we're on and we're active
and erm would you like to tell me how long you've lived in in ?
right erm so then you've probably got more of a local accent than anybody
I would so say so yeah I mean
some people say I've got a real accent but I I don't really take any notice of it
and I I know you've been in a family business for years
erm and you're erm er a carpenter by trade?
and erm what sort of work do you do?
well carpentry joinery buildings extensions conversions anything really in the b in the construction line really
what do you favour yourself mostly?
erm the joinery side of things making windows doors staircases and maybe putting kitchens in and
right and so where did you learn your trade?

er I learnt my trade with my father I was er he sort of er said why don't you come on and work for me? so I said alright and I'll give it a go sort of thing cos er I I I'd left school about four years and hadn't really sort of thought about doing that and erm then started and never looked back
right I see and er but you didn't actually go formally to college? you were an apprenticeship?
oh yeah yeah I done a full apprenticeship four
going through erm the basic three years carpentry and joinery and then the one years of arts craft
whwhere did you go? did you go to?
well I had to go travel for that I had for the first three years I had to go to college
erm because they didn't run the course in and then on my advanced craft I could do it in because they were running the course then
right right things were very different in those days weren't they? because erm college used to be a really top notch place for
and it's it's changed the way they run the apprenticeships are
not not good for the the construction industry
no I'm sure they're not erm
the erm I I mean I did an art degree erm five years ago erm at college with university
erm and it was very different and er the principal has got rid of all the erm art erm
yeah at that level there aren't any degree courses for fine art now I think I was the
penultimate well there was one other after my course erm but anyway iit er was the college of arts and technology erm and it all she's really interested in in hairdressing apparently
the according to the tutors who all got made redundant they were quite you know cross about that anyway back to you which is far more important so you're a model engineer today and you're
and you're here to do the working party yeah?
well I've I've stopped in just to drop some materials off really
for for for all the rest of them to do something
oh ri yes well that's right line them up and get them
and get them get them working
yeah give them something to work with
erm and erm and so you've been in the model engineers for how long?
erm oh on and off for oh m expect thirty years really I suppose
but er I dropped away for a for quite a while it was probably ten or fifteen years erm really not having so much to do with it cos it was more my father's hobby

erm unfortunately when he passed away I decided that you know I'd come and sort of help them do a few bits and pieces and then er I've got back into it a bit more since then but er yeah it's it's really er I'm but I've been involved in some res way or form for a long time really
what are you working on at the moment?
er well I've erm j not not on the model engineering side except for they've just made three carriages or three carriage
bases in there which I'll make all the woodwork tops for
erm cos they're hoping to have a an open day next year
erm and they want some extra carriages
oh right yes I've heard about the open day that that should be interesting
I think there are several schools of thought on that aren't there?
yes there's a yes there's erm
it's er should be interesting anyway but er yeah so we can get the carriages made and I'm also making a couple of my own so
I'll get those as well and then they'll have plenty of er carriages to run on their railway here
jolly good jolly good that's great erm because erm this model engineers is in a park here isn't it? can you tell can you describe the park to me this morning?

er yes the park's erm probably about er five hundred yards across and five hundred y six or seven hundred yards deep erm it's er originally was a recreation field erm with a football pitch erm with some tennis courts on the side the tennis courts got very badly vandalised and er disused and we were invited here by the parish council erm to er rent a bit of land and to give the parish council some income at that time erm so that er they could carry on doing other things and then we've built a track round the periphery of the park erm which er you know we've got a track running all the way around that does a complete loop tack to a turntable at the other end
right yeah and erm it it's a lov er it is a lovely park

yeah and the we're we're very near the motorway in the background you can hear the motorway erm and that's that's not a problem erm I used to live in and have this noise all the time and it didn't worry me after a while you don't notice it do you?
no to be honest you don't I mean

we we work next to a railway line in our workshop and people have come in to us before and said christ bet you enjoy this cos the trains aren't running today and you go what trains? cos you really don't take any notice of the
you know m it's right next to the main line
well I mean also I expect you've got a lot of equipment on the go haven't you? noisy equipment
yeah there's a lot of times yeah
and you've got ear defenders on I expect and all that sort of thing
most of the time yeah yeah
so you wouldn't so erm I know that your father was instrumental and your family in building the large building here
that's it yeah was erm the the carriage was the carriage shed er there was named in his honour after unfortunately after he passed away
and they named it in his honour and cos because he was sort of like the driving force behind it if you like
erm in getting it built and that well and for the model engineers for a quite a whi you know a long a lot of years really
he was er very much involved from about nineteen eighty I think when park
erm so yeah it's er it's nice to sort of like er have the knowledge that there's something's named in his er honour out here really you know
it's quite a privilege really yeah
wonderful given the local politics you know that ebb and flow around the place erm it's great that h you managed to get it up really
this is it yeah this is it
er yeah it is really considering er you know wha well considering we had a lot of vandalism to start with because
whenever night time when all people went home somebody f kind person from the village used to come up and push the walls over

yeah sort of thing just sort of and they did find out it was one particular person er I don't know who it was now but lived in a bungalow down across the way and he could see it being put up during the day and obviously didn't like the idea of somebody building up here and come up in the night time and pushed the walls over
I did hear cos the twenty years ago when I met I was living in

and I had a house in fact they're building in you know at the back of it now and I'm gl jolly glad I was always worried that they were going to build cos there was a lovely field behind and erm one of the things that was in the news at the time was about the bulldozer?
and it how it bulldozed the pavilion down?
and I remember that and when later they said oh they're going out to I said oh ththey mustn't do that and now
yeah and so now I've heard that you you know you had trouble with your builder
yeah this is it yeah as we've built it up they they'd come up the next day or the next week
and find all the walls were pushed over sort of thing and had to rebuild them
oh how do you feel about that?
well it's I just think this is just there's er ththere's too many people with er too much time on their hands if they can come up and do that you know
they'd rather vandalise something than actually construct something
you know and er they you know instead of just coming along and saying well you know why are you here? and why do you wanna be here? and understand the reasons for it
they'd rather just come up on their own and erm
yes I mean even if you ask them to to join and come they probably wouldn't come
no no but they'd rather you know they'd rather spoil everybody else's thing and
they cost people money at the end of the day you know and
and I think at the end of the day it was criminal damage as well you know
erm h did you ever feel at any time about giving up? I mean given the situation?
well I mean I wasn't that involved at that point
erm I mean it was because it was more my father's hobby

I thought no you know he's happy doing that and it's his hobby er and it wasn't until after he went we sort of we said well you know we just will go out there and help er do finish off something he started cos
it was very unusual because usually he was helping finish something we started
erm so we thought we'd go out and sort of help finish it and we were out here sort of thing erm and the clubhouse had been finished by that point
erm but I mean I know when he used to come back and he used to say you know sort of thing people had been up here and vandalised it they you know
they spent a day building walls and had to then
sort of thing which is really
definitely erm one of the things that really I really admire about the model engineers above any other society is that they're all well you all are craftsmen and you're all engineers
and that you all make things and sometimes from scratch erm mostly from scratch erm er was saying he spends three hours a day in his workshop
and if he can't go in he gets grumpy

er well I no I well I I enjoy getting away
from the work I have to admit
yeah yeah I do enjoy getting away from the work

so er I enjoy sort of
like er using that which is er something so that's my escape from work and that's
that's on a marina down in and er
iif I'm down there I can't be on the phone just
somebody can't get hold of me easily to say come and do this and come and do that
because the phone is always on twenty-four seven but erm
I mean it's nice to be away and then you can say well I'm too far away to cocome and do it you know?
yes exactly and you don't take a mobile with you obviously

erm it was twenty twenty-four feet feet long

you know you've got a little cooker and fridge and
just just just er pleasurable to get out and get out on the sea really
so erm are you you're not nervous obviously about taking it out?
erm what what sort of weather would put you off?
erm to be honest as long as long as we're under sort of twenty-two miles an hour
we're we're alright and then it depends on the direction of the wind er down in er where I'm in if it's easterlies

usually the sea stays fairly flat
